title: Paint Coverage Calculator

seo.title: Paint Coverage Calculator - Estimate Paint Needed for Walls & Ceilings
seo.description: Calculate precisely how much paint you'll need for your room or project. Avoid overbuying or running out with our accurate paint coverage estimator.

inputs.label: Paint Coverage
inputs.description: Average square feet per gallon (check paint can)

inputs.label: Total Door Area
inputs.description: Combined area of all doors (e.g., 20 sqft per standard door)

inputs.label: Total Window Area
inputs.description: Combined area of all windows (e.g., 15 sqft per standard window)

formula: const wallArea = 2 * (roomLength + roomWidth) * roomHeight; const ceilingArea = roomLength * roomWidth; const totalPaintableArea = wallArea + ceilingArea - doorsArea - windowsArea; const totalSqFtToCover = totalPaintableArea * numCoats; const gallonsNeeded = totalSqFtToCover / paintCoveragePerGallon; return {totalPaintableArea, gallonsNeeded};

faq.question: How do I measure for paint?
faq.answer: Measure the length, width, and height of your room. Subtract the areas of any doors and windows that will not be painted. Most paint calculations assume painting walls and ceilings.

faq.question: How much does a gallon of paint cover?
faq.answer: On average, a gallon of paint covers about 350-400 square feet with one coat. However, this can vary based on the paint type, surface porosity, and application method. Always check the manufacturer's recommendations on the paint can.

faq.question: How many coats of paint do I need?
faq.answer: Most painting projects require two coats for good coverage and durability, especially when changing a color significantly or painting over a darker color. Primer might be needed for very porous surfaces or drastic color changes.

faq.question: Should I buy extra paint?
faq.answer: It's always a good idea to buy a little extra paint (e.g., 10-15%) for touch-ups later. Make sure to keep the leftover paint in a sealed can in a cool, dry place.
